headers.toc1: The First Book of Moses, called Genesis
headers.mt1: The First Book of Moses, called Genesis

verses.text: In the beginning God created the heaven and the earth.

And the earth was without form, and void; and darkness \add was\add*
upon the face of the deep. And the Spirit of God moved upon the face
of the waters.
And God said, Let there be light: and there was light.

And God saw the light, that \add it was\add* good: and God
divided the light from the darkness.\f + \fr 1.4  \ft the light from…: Heb. between the light and between the
darkness\f*

And God called the light Day, and the darkness he called Night.
And the evening and the morning were the first day.\f + \fr 1.5 
\ft And the evening…: Heb. And the evening was, and the morning was
etc.\f*

¶ And God said, Let there be a firmament in the midst of the
waters, and let it divide the waters from the waters.\f + \fr 1.6 
\ft firmament: Heb. expansion\f*

And God made the firmament, and divided the waters which \add were\add*
under the firmament from the waters which \add were\add* above the
firmament: and it was so.

And God called the firmament Heaven. And the evening and the
morning were the second day.\f + \fr 1.8  \ft And the evening…: Heb. And the evening was, and the morning was
etc.\f*

¶ And God said, Let the waters under the heaven be gathered
together unto one place, and let the dry \add land\add* appear: and it was so.

And God called the dry \add land\add* Earth; and the gathering
together of the waters called he Seas: and God saw that \add it was\add*
good.

And God said, Let the earth bring forth grass, the herb yielding
seed, \add and\add* the fruit tree yielding fruit after his kind,
whose seed \add is\add* in itself, upon the earth: and it was so.\f + \fr 1.11 
\ft grass: Heb. tender grass\f*

And the earth brought forth grass, \add and\add* herb yielding
seed after his kind, and the tree yielding  fruit, whose seed \add was\add*
in itself, after his kind: and God saw that \add it was\add* good.

And the evening and the morning were the third day.\f + \fr 1.13 
\ft And the evening…: Heb. And the evening was, and the morning was
etc.\f*

¶ And God said, Let there be lights in the firmament of the
heaven to divide the day from the night; and let them be for signs,
and for seasons, and for days, and years:\f + \fr 1.14  \ft the day…: Heb. between the day and between the
night\f*

And let them be for lights in the firmament of the heaven
to give light upon the earth: and it was so.

And God made two great lights; the greater light to rule the
day, and the lesser light to rule the night: \add he made\add* the
stars also.\f + \fr 1.16  \ft to rule the day…: Heb. for the rule of the day,
etc.\f*

And God set them in the firmament of the heaven to give light
upon the earth,

And to rule over the day and over the night, and to divide
the light from the darkness: and God saw that \add it was\add* good.

And the evening and the morning were the fourth day.\f + \fr 1.19 
\ft And the evening…: Heb. And the evening was, and the morning was
etc.\f*

And God said, Let the waters bring forth abundantly the moving
creature that hath life, and fowl \add that\add* may fly above the
earth in the open firmament of heaven.\f + \fr 1.20  \ft moving: or,
creeping\f*\f + \fr 1.20  \ft life: Heb. soul\f*\f + \fr 1.20  \ft fowl…: Heb. let fowl
fly\f*\f + \fr 1.20  \ft open…: Heb. face of the firmament of heaven\f*

And God created great whales, and every living creature that
moveth, which the waters brought forth abundantly, after their kind,
and every winged fowl after his kind: and God saw that \add it was\add*
good.

And God blessed them, saying, Be fruitful, and multiply, and
fill the waters in the seas, and let fowl multiply  in the earth.

And the evening and the morning were the fifth day.\f + \fr 1.23 
\ft And the evening…: Heb. And the evening was, and the morning was
etc.\f*

¶ And God said, Let the earth bring forth the living creature
after his kind, cattle, and creeping thing, and beast of the earth
after his kind: and it was so.

And God made the beast of the earth after his kind, and cattle
after their kind, and every thing that creepeth upon the earth after his
kind: and God saw that \add it was\add* good.

¶ And God said, Let us make man in our image, after our likeness:
and let them have dominion over the fish of the sea, and over the
fowl of the air, and over the cattle, and over all the earth, and over every creeping
thing that creepeth upon the earth.

So God created man in his \add own\add* image, in the image
of God created he him; male and female created he them.

And God blessed them, and God said unto them, Be fruitful,
and multiply, and replenish the earth, and subdue it: and have dominion
over the fish of the sea, and over the fowl of the air, and over every living
thing that moveth upon the earth.\f + \fr 1.28  \ft moveth: Heb.
creepeth\f*

¶ And God said, Behold, I have given you every herb bearing
 seed, which \add is\add* upon the face of all the earth, and every
tree, in the which \add is\add* the fruit of a tree yielding seed;
to you it shall be for meat.\f + \fr 1.29  \ft bearing…: Heb. seeding
seed\f*\f + \fr 1.29  \ft yielding…: Heb. seeding seed\f*

And to every beast of the earth, and to every fowl of the
air, and to every thing that creepeth upon the earth, wherein \add there
is\add* life, \add I have given\add* every green herb for meat: and it was
so.\f + \fr 1.30  \ft life: Heb. a living soul\f*

And God saw every thing that he had made, and, behold, \add it
was\add* very good. And the evening and the morning were the sixth
day.\f + \fr 1.31  \ft And the evening…: Heb. And the evening was, and the morning was
etc.\f*

Thus the heavens and the earth were finished, and all the host of
them.

And on the seventh day God ended his work which he had made;
and he rested on the seventh day from all his work which he had made.

And God blessed the seventh day, and sanctified it: because
that in it he had rested from all his work which God created and
made.\f + \fr 2.3  \ft created…: Heb. created to make\f*

¶ These \add are\add* the generations of the heavens and of the
earth when they were created, in the day that the \nd LORD\nd* God
made the earth and the heavens,

And every plant of the field before it was in the earth, and every
herb of the field before it grew: for the \nd LORD\nd* God had not
caused it to rain upon the earth, and \add there was\add* not a man
to till the ground.

But there went up a mist from the earth, and watered the whole
face of the ground.\f + \fr 2.6  \ft there…: or, a mist which went up from,
etc.\f*

And the \nd LORD\nd* God formed man \add of\add* the dust of
the ground, and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life; and
man became a living soul.\f + \fr 2.7  \ft of the dust…: Heb. dust of the
ground\f*

¶ And the \nd LORD\nd* God planted a garden eastward in Eden;
and there he put the man whom he had formed.

And out of the ground made the \nd LORD\nd* God to grow every
tree that is pleasant to the sight, and good for food; the tree of
life also in the midst of the garden, and the tree of knowledge of
good and evil.

And a river went out of Eden to water the garden; and from thence it was
parted, and became into four heads.

And the gold of that land \add is\add* good: there \add is\add*
bdellium and the onyx stone.

And the name of the second river \add is\add* Gihon: the same
\add is\add* it that compasseth the whole land of Ethiopia.\f + \fr 2.13 
\ft Ethiopia: Heb. Cush\f*

And the name of the third river \add is\add* Hiddekel: that
\add is\add* it which goeth toward the east of Assyria. And the fourth
river \add is\add* Euphrates.\f + \fr 2.14  \ft toward…: or, eastward to
Assyria\f*

And the \nd LORD\nd* God took the man, and put him into the
garden of Eden to dress it and to keep it.\f + \fr 2.15  \ft the man: or,
Adam\f*

And the \nd LORD\nd* God commanded the man, saying, Of every
tree of the garden thou mayest freely eat:\f + \fr 2.16  \ft thou…: Heb. eating thou shalt
eat\f*

But of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, thou shalt not
eat of it: for in the day that thou eatest thereof thou shalt surely
die.\f + \fr 2.17  \ft thou shalt surely…: Heb. dying thou shalt
die\f*

¶ And the \nd LORD\nd* God said, \add It is\add* not good that the
man should be alone; I will make him an help meet for him.\f + \fr 2.18 
\ft meet…: Heb. as before him\f*

And out of the ground the \nd LORD\nd* God formed every beast
of the field, and every fowl of the air; and brought \add them\add*
unto Adam to see what he would call them: and whatsoever Adam called
every living creature, that \add was\add* the name thereof.\f + \fr 2.19 
\ft Adam: or, the man\f*

And Adam gave names to all cattle, and to the fowl of the
air, and to every beast of the field; but for Adam there was not
found an help meet for him.\f + \fr 2.20  \ft gave: Heb. called\f*

And the rib, which the \nd LORD\nd* God had taken from man,
made he a woman, and brought her unto the man.\f + \fr 2.22  \ft made: Heb.
builded\f*

And Adam said, This \add is\add* now bone of my bones, and
flesh of my flesh: she shall be called Woman, because she was taken
out of Man.\f + \fr 2.23  \ft Woman: Heb. Isha\f*\f + \fr 2.23  \ft Man: Heb.
Ish\f*

Therefore shall a man leave his father and his mother, and shall
cleave unto his wife: and they shall be one flesh.

And they were both naked, the man and his wife, and were not
ashamed.

Now the serpent was more subtil than any beast of the field
which the \nd LORD\nd* God had made. And he said unto the woman,
Yea, hath God said, Ye shall not eat of every tree of the garden?\f + \fr 3.1 
\ft Yea…: Heb. Yea, because, etc.\f*

And the woman said unto the serpent, We may eat of the fruit
of the trees of the garden:

But of the fruit of the tree which \add is\add* in the midst
of the garden, God hath said, Ye shall not eat of it, neither shall ye
touch it, lest ye die.
And the serpent said unto the woman, Ye shall not surely die:

For God doth know that in the day ye eat thereof, then your
eyes shall be opened, and ye shall be as gods, knowing good and evil.

And when the woman saw that the tree \add was\add* good for
food, and that it \add was\add* pleasant to the eyes, and a tree
to be desired to make \add one\add* wise, she took of the fruit thereof,
and did eat, and gave also unto her husband with her; and he did
eat.\f + \fr 3.6  \ft pleasant: Heb. a desire\f*

And the eyes of them both were opened, and they knew that they
\add were\add* naked; and they sewed fig leaves together, and made
themselves aprons.\f + \fr 3.7  \ft aprons: or, things to gird about\f*

And they heard the voice of the \nd LORD\nd* God walking in the
garden in the cool of the day: and Adam and his wife hid themselves
from the presence of the \nd LORD\nd* God amongst the trees of the
garden.\f + \fr 3.8  \ft cool: Heb. wind\f*

And the \nd LORD\nd* God called unto Adam, and said unto him, Where
\add art\add* thou?

And he said, I heard thy voice in the garden, and I was afraid,
because I \add was\add* naked; and I hid myself.

And he said, Who told thee that thou \add wast\add* naked?
Hast thou eaten of the tree, whereof I commanded thee that thou shouldest
not eat?

And the man said, The woman whom thou gavest \add to be\add*
with me, she gave me of the tree, and I did eat.

And the \nd LORD\nd* God said unto the woman, What \add is\add* this
\add that\add* thou hast done? And the woman said, The serpent beguiled
me, and I did eat.

And the \nd LORD\nd* God said unto the serpent, Because thou
hast done this, thou \add art\add* cursed above all cattle, and above every
beast of the field; upon thy belly shalt thou go, and dust shalt thou
eat all the days of thy life:

And I will put enmity between thee and the woman, and between thy
seed and her seed; it shall bruise thy head, and thou shalt bruise
his heel.

Unto the woman he said, I will greatly multiply thy sorrow
and thy conception; in sorrow thou shalt bring forth children; and thy
desire \add shall be\add* to thy husband, and he shall rule over
thee.\f + \fr 3.16  \ft to thy…: or, subject to thy husband\f*

And unto Adam he said, Because thou hast hearkened unto the
voice of thy wife, and hast eaten of the tree, of which I commanded
thee, saying, Thou shalt not eat of it: cursed \add is\add* the ground
for thy sake; in sorrow shalt thou eat \add of\add* it all the days
of thy life;

Thorns also and thistles shall it bring forth to thee; and thou shalt
eat the herb of the field;\f + \fr 3.18  \ft bring…: Heb. cause to
bud\f*

In the sweat of thy face shalt thou eat bread, till thou return
unto the ground; for out of it wast thou taken: for dust thou \add art\add*,
and unto dust shalt thou return.

And Adam called his wife’s name Eve; because she was the mother
of all living.\f + \fr 3.20  \ft Eve: Heb. Chavah: that is Living\f*

Unto Adam also and to his wife did the \nd LORD\nd* God make
coats of skins, and clothed them.

¶ And the \nd LORD\nd* God said, Behold, the man is become as
one of us, to know good and evil: and now, lest he put forth his
hand, and take also of the tree of life, and eat, and live for ever:

Therefore the \nd LORD\nd* God sent him forth from the garden
of Eden, to till the ground from whence he was taken.

So he drove out the man; and he placed at the east of the
garden of Eden Cherubims, and a flaming sword which turned every
way, to keep the way of the tree of life.

And Adam knew Eve his wife; and she conceived, and bare Cain,
and said, I have gotten a man from the \nd LORD\nd*.\f + \fr 4.1 
\ft Cain: that is, Gotten, or, Acquired\f*

And she again bare his brother Abel. And Abel was a keeper
of sheep, but Cain was a tiller of the ground.\f + \fr 4.2  \ft Abel: Heb.
Hebel\f*\f + \fr 4.2  \ft a keeper: Heb. a feeder\f*

And in process of time it came to pass, that Cain brought of the
fruit of the ground an offering unto the \nd LORD\nd*.\f + \fr 4.3 
\ft in process…: Heb. at the end of days\f*

And Abel, he also brought of the firstlings of his flock and of the
fat thereof. And the \nd LORD\nd* had respect unto Abel and to his
offering:\f + \fr 4.4  \ft flock: Heb. sheep, or, goats\f*

But unto Cain and to his offering he had not respect. And Cain
was very wroth, and his countenance fell.

And the \nd LORD\nd* said unto Cain, Why art thou wroth? and why is thy
countenance fallen?

If thou doest well, shalt thou not be accepted? and if thou doest not
well, sin lieth at the door. And unto thee \add shall be\add* his
desire, and thou shalt rule over him.\f + \fr 4.7  \ft be accepted: or, have the
excellency\f*\f + \fr 4.7  \ft unto…: or, subject unto thee\f*

And Cain talked with Abel his brother: and it came to pass, when they were in the
field, that Cain rose up against Abel his brother, and slew him.

¶ And the \nd LORD\nd* said unto Cain, Where \add is\add* Abel
thy brother? And he said, I know not: \add Am\add* I my brother’s
keeper?

And he said, What hast thou done? the voice of thy brother’s
blood crieth unto me from the ground.\f + \fr 4.10  \ft blood: Heb.
bloods\f*

And now \add art\add* thou cursed from the earth, which hath
opened her mouth to receive thy brother’s blood from thy hand;

When thou tillest the ground, it shall not henceforth yield
unto thee her strength; a fugitive and a vagabond shalt thou be in the
earth.

And Cain said unto the \nd LORD\nd*, My punishment \add is\add*
greater than I can bear.\f + \fr 4.13  \ft My…: or, Mine iniquity is greater than that it may be
forgiven\f*

Behold, thou hast driven me out this day from the face of the
earth; and from thy face shall I be hid; and I shall be a fugitive
and a vagabond in the earth; and it shall come to pass, \add that\add*
every one that findeth me shall slay me.

And the \nd LORD\nd* said unto him, Therefore whosoever slayeth
Cain, vengeance shall be taken on him sevenfold. And the \nd LORD\nd*
set a mark upon Cain, lest any finding him should kill him.

¶ And Cain went out from the presence of the \nd LORD\nd*,
and dwelt in the land of Nod, on the east of Eden.

And Cain knew his wife; and she conceived, and bare Enoch:
and he builded a city, and called the name of the city, after the
name of his son, Enoch.\f + \fr 4.17  \ft Enoch: Heb. Chanoch\f*

And unto Enoch was born Irad: and Irad begat Mehujael: and
Mehujael begat Methusael: and Methusael begat Lamech.\f + \fr 4.18 
\ft Lamech: Heb. Lemech\f*

¶ And Lamech took unto him two wives: the name of the one \add was\add*
Adah, and the name of the other Zillah.

And Adah bare Jabal: he was the father of such as dwell in
tents, and \add of such as have\add* cattle.

And his brother’s name \add was\add* Jubal: he was the father
of all such as handle the harp and organ.

And Zillah, she also bare Tubal-cain, an instructer of every
artificer in brass and iron: and the sister of Tubal-cain \add was\add*
Naamah.\f + \fr 4.22  \ft instructer: Heb. whetter\f*

And Lamech said unto his wives, Adah and Zillah, Hear my voice;
ye wives of Lamech, hearken unto my speech: for I have slain a man
to my wounding, and a young man to my hurt.\f + \fr 4.23  \ft I have…: or, I would slay a man in my wound,
etc.\f*\f + \fr 4.23  \ft to my hurt: or, in my hurt\f*

If Cain shall be avenged sevenfold, truly Lamech seventy and
sevenfold.

¶ And Adam knew his wife again; and she bare a son, and called
his name Seth: For God, \add said she\add*, hath appointed me another
seed instead of Abel, whom Cain slew.\f + \fr 4.25  \ft Seth: Heb. Sheth: that is Appointed, or,
Put\f*

And to Seth, to him also there was born a son; and he called
his name Enos: then began men to call upon the name of the \nd LORD\nd*.\f + \fr 4.26 
\ft Enos: Heb. Enosh\f*\f + \fr 4.26  \ft to call…: or, to call themselves by the name of the
Lord\f*

This \add is\add* the book of the generations of Adam. In the
day that God created man, in the likeness of God made he him;

Male and female created he them; and blessed them, and called
their name Adam, in the day when they were created.

¶ And Adam lived an hundred and thirty years, and begat \add a
son\add* in his own likeness, after his image; and called his name
Seth:

And the days of Adam after he had begotten Seth were eight
hundred years: and he begat sons and daughters:

And all the days that Adam lived were nine hundred and thirty
years: and he died.

And Seth lived an hundred and five years, and begat Enos:\f + \fr 5.6 
\ft Enos: Heb. Enosh\f*

And Seth lived after he begat Enos eight hundred and seven
years, and begat sons and daughters:

And all the days of Seth were nine hundred and twelve years:
and he died.

¶ And Enos lived ninety years, and begat Cainan:\f + \fr 5.9 
\ft Cainan: Heb. Kenan\f*

And Enos lived after he begat Cainan eight hundred and fifteen
years, and begat sons and daughters:

And all the days of Enos were nine hundred and five years:
and he died.

¶ And Cainan lived seventy years, and begat Mahalaleel:\f + \fr 5.12 
\ft Mahalaleel: Gr. Maleleel\f*

And Cainan lived after he begat Mahalaleel eight hundred and
forty years, and begat sons and daughters:

And all the days of Cainan were nine hundred and ten years:
and he died.

¶ And Mahalaleel lived sixty and five years, and begat Jared:\f + \fr 5.15 
\ft Jared: Heb. Jered\f*

And Mahalaleel lived after he begat Jared eight hundred and
thirty years, and begat sons and daughters:

And all the days of Mahalaleel were eight hundred ninety and
five years: and he died.

¶ And Jared lived an hundred sixty and two years, and he begat
Enoch:

And Jared lived after he begat Enoch eight hundred years,
and begat sons and daughters:

And all the days of Jared were nine hundred sixty and two
years: and he died.

¶ And Enoch lived sixty and five years, and begat Methuselah:\f + \fr 5.21 
\ft Methuselah: Gr. Mathusala\f*

And Enoch walked with God after he begat Methuselah three
hundred years, and begat sons and daughters:

And all the days of Enoch were three hundred sixty and five
years:

And Enoch walked with God: and he \add was\add* not; for God
took him.

And Methuselah lived an hundred eighty and seven years, and
begat Lamech:

And Methuselah lived after he begat Lamech seven hundred eighty
and two years, and begat sons and daughters:\f + \fr 5.26  \ft Lamech: Heb.
Lemech\f*

And all the days of Methuselah were nine hundred sixty and
nine years: and he died.

¶ And Lamech lived an hundred eighty and two years, and begat
a son:

And he called his name Noah, saying, This \add same\add* shall
comfort us concerning our work and toil of our hands, because of the
ground which the \nd LORD\nd* hath cursed.\f + \fr 5.29  \ft Noah: Gr. Noe: that is Rest, or,
Comfort\f*

And Lamech lived after he begat Noah five hundred ninety and
five years, and begat sons and daughters:

And all the days of Lamech were seven hundred seventy and
seven years: and he died.

And Noah was five hundred years old: and Noah begat Shem,
Ham, and Japheth.

And it came to pass, when men began to multiply on the face
of the earth, and daughters were born unto them,

That the sons of God saw the daughters of men that they \add were\add*
fair; and they took them wives of all which they chose.

And the \nd LORD\nd* said, My spirit shall not always strive
with man, for that he also \add is\add* flesh: yet his days shall be an
hundred and twenty years.

There were giants in the earth in those days; and also after
that, when the sons of God came in unto the daughters of men, and they
bare \add children\add* to them, the same \add became\add* mighty
men which \add were\add* of old, men of renown.

¶ And \nd GOD\nd* saw that the wickedness of man \add was\add*
great in the earth, and \add that\add* every imagination of the thoughts
of his heart \add was\add* only evil continually.\f + \fr 6.5  \ft every…: or, the whole imagination: the Hebrew word
signifieth not only the imagination, but also the purposes and desires\f*\f + \fr 6.5 
\ft continually: Heb. every day\f*

And it repented the \nd LORD\nd* that he had made man on the
earth, and it grieved him at his heart.

And the \nd LORD\nd* said, I will destroy man whom I have created
from the face of the earth; both man, and beast, and the creeping
thing, and the fowls of the air; for it repenteth me that I have
made them.\f + \fr 6.7  \ft both…: Heb. from man unto beast\f*
But Noah found grace in the eyes of the \nd LORD\nd*.

¶ These \add are\add* the generations of Noah: Noah was a just
man \add and\add* perfect in his generations, \add and\add* Noah
walked with God.\f + \fr 6.9  \ft perfect: or, upright\f*
And Noah begat three sons, Shem, Ham, and Japheth.

The earth also was corrupt before God, and the earth was filled
with violence.

And God looked upon the earth, and, behold, it was corrupt;
for all flesh had corrupted his way upon the earth.

And God said unto Noah, The end of all flesh is come before
me; for the earth is filled with violence through them; and, behold, I will
destroy them with the earth.\f + \fr 6.13  \ft with the earth: or, from the
earth\f*

¶ Make thee an ark of gopher wood; rooms shalt thou make in
the ark, and shalt pitch it within and without with pitch.\f + \fr 6.14 
\ft rooms: Heb. nests\f*

And this \add is the fashion\add* which thou shalt make it
\add of:\add* The length of the ark \add shall be\add* three hundred
cubits, the breadth of it fifty cubits, and the height of it thirty
cubits.

A window shalt thou make to the ark, and in a cubit shalt thou
finish it above; and the door of the ark shalt thou set in the side
thereof; \add with\add* lower, second, and third \add stories\add*
shalt thou make it.

And, behold, I, even I, do bring a flood of waters upon the
earth, to destroy all flesh, wherein \add is\add* the breath of life,
from under heaven; \add and\add* every thing that \add is\add* in the
earth shall die.

But with thee will I establish my covenant; and thou shalt
come into the ark, thou, and thy sons, and thy wife, and thy sons’
wives with thee.

And of every living thing of all flesh, two of every \add sort\add*
shalt thou bring into the ark, to keep \add them\add* alive with thee; they shall be
male and female.

Of fowls after their kind, and of cattle after their kind,
of every creeping thing of the earth after his kind, two of every
\add sort\add* shall come unto thee, to keep \add them\add* alive.

And take thou unto thee of all food that is eaten, and thou shalt
gather \add it\add* to thee; and it shall be for food for thee, and for them.

Thus did Noah; according to all that God commanded him, so
did he.

And the \nd LORD\nd* said unto Noah, Come thou and all thy
house into the ark; for thee have I seen righteous before me in this
generation.

Of every clean beast thou shalt take to thee by sevens, the
male and his female: and of beasts that \add are\add* not clean by
two, the male and his female.\f + \fr 7.2  \ft by sevens: Heb. seven
seven\f*

For yet seven days, and I will cause it to rain upon the earth
forty days and forty nights; and every living substance that I have
made will I destroy from off the face of the earth.\f + \fr 7.4 
\ft destroy: Heb. blot out\f*
And Noah did according unto all that the \nd LORD\nd* commanded him.

And Noah \add was\add* six hundred years old when the flood
of waters was upon the earth.

¶ And Noah went in, and his sons, and his wife, and his sons’

peace.

And it came to pass the same day, that Isaac’s servants came,
and told him concerning the well which they had digged, and said
unto him, We have found water.

And he called it Shebah: therefore the name of the city \add is\add*
Beer-sheba unto this day.\f + \fr 26.33  \ft Shebah: That is, an
oath\f*\f + \fr 26.33  \ft Beer-sheba: that is, the well of the oath\f*

¶ And Esau was forty years old when he took to wife Judith
the daughter of Beeri the Hittite, and Bashemath the daughter of
Elon the Hittite:

Which were a grief of mind unto Isaac and to Rebekah.\f + \fr 26.35 
\ft a grief…: Heb. bitterness of spirit\f*

And it came to pass, that when Isaac was old, and his eyes
were dim, so that he could not see, he called Esau his eldest son,
and said unto him, My son: and he said unto him, Behold, \add here
am\add* I.

And he said, Behold now, I am old, I know not the day of my
death:

Now therefore take, I pray thee, thy weapons, thy quiver and thy
bow, and go out to the field, and take me \add some\add* venison;\f + \fr 27.3 
\ft take: Heb. hunt\f*

And make me savoury meat, such as I love, and bring \add it\add*
to me, that I may eat; that my soul may bless thee before I die.

And Rebekah heard when Isaac spake to Esau his son. And Esau
went to the field to hunt \add for\add* venison, \add and\add* to
bring \add it\add*.

¶ And Rebekah spake unto Jacob her son, saying, Behold, I heard
thy father speak unto Esau thy brother, saying,

Bring me venison, and make me savoury meat, that I may eat,
and bless thee before the \nd LORD\nd* before my death.

Now therefore, my son, obey my voice according to that which
I command thee.

Go now to the flock, and fetch me from thence two good kids
of the goats; and I will make them savoury meat for thy father, such as he
loveth:

And thou shalt bring \add it\add* to thy father, that he may
eat, and that he may bless thee before his death.

And Jacob said to Rebekah his mother, Behold, Esau my brother
\add is\add* a hairy man, and I \add am\add* a smooth man:

My father peradventure will feel me, and I shall seem to him as a
deceiver; and I shall bring a curse upon me, and not a blessing.

And his mother said unto him, Upon me \add be\add* thy curse,
my son: only obey my voice, and go fetch me \add them\add*.

And he went, and fetched, and brought \add them\add* to his
mother: and his mother made savoury meat, such as his father loved.

And Rebekah took goodly raiment of her eldest son Esau, which
\add were\add* with her in the house, and put them upon Jacob her
younger son:\f + \fr 27.15  \ft goodly: Heb. desirable\f*

And she put the skins of the kids of the goats upon his hands,
and upon the smooth of his neck:

And she gave the savoury meat and the bread, which she had
prepared, into the hand of her son Jacob.

¶ And he came unto his father, and said, My father: and he
said, Here \add am\add* I; who \add art\add* thou, my son?

And Isaac said unto his son, How \add is it\add* that thou hast
found \add it\add* so quickly, my son? And he said, Because the \nd LORD\nd*
thy God brought \add it\add* to me.\f + \fr 27.20  \ft to me: Heb. before
me\f*

And Isaac said unto Jacob, Come near, I pray thee, that I may
feel thee, my son, whether thou \add be\add* my very son Esau or not.

And Jacob went near unto Isaac his father; and he felt him, and
said, The voice \add is\add* Jacob’s voice, but the hands \add are\add*
the hands of Esau.

And he discerned him not, because his hands were hairy, as his
brother Esau’s hands: so he blessed him.

And he said, \add Art\add* thou my very son Esau? And he said, I
\add am\add*.

And he said, Bring \add it\add* near to me, and I will eat
of my son’s venison, that my soul may bless thee. And he brought
\add it\add* near to him, and he did eat: and he brought him wine,
and he drank.

And his father Isaac said unto him, Come near now, and kiss
me, my son.

And he came near, and kissed him: and he smelled the smell
of his raiment, and blessed him, and said, See, the smell of my son
\add is\add* as the smell of a field which the \nd LORD\nd* hath
blessed:

Therefore God give thee of the dew of heaven, and the fatness
of the earth, and plenty of corn and wine:

Let people serve thee, and nations bow down to thee: be lord
over thy brethren, and let thy mother’s sons bow down to thee: cursed
\add be\add* every one that curseth thee, and blessed \add be\add*
he that blesseth thee.

¶ And it came to pass, as soon as Isaac had made an end of
blessing Jacob, and Jacob was yet scarce gone out from the presence
of Isaac his father, that Esau his brother came in from his hunting.

And he also had made savoury meat, and brought it unto his
father, and said unto his father, Let my father arise, and eat of his
son’s venison, that thy soul may bless me.

And Isaac his father said unto him, Who \add art\add* thou? And he
said, I \add am\add* thy son, thy firstborn Esau.

And Isaac trembled very exceedingly, and said, Who? where
\add is\add* he that hath taken venison, and brought \add it\add*
me, and I have eaten of all before thou camest, and have blessed him? yea,
\add and\add* he shall be blessed.\f + \fr 27.33  \ft trembled…: Heb. trembled with a great trembling
greatly\f*\f + \fr 27.33  \ft taken: Heb. hunted\f*

And when Esau heard the words of his father, he cried with a
great and exceeding bitter cry, and said unto his father, Bless me,
\add even\add* me also, O my father.

And he said, Thy brother came with subtilty, and hath taken
away thy blessing.

And he said, Is not he rightly named Jacob? for he hath supplanted
me these two times: he took away my birthright; and, behold, now he hath taken
away my blessing. And he said, Hast thou not reserved a blessing for
me?\f + \fr 27.36  \ft Jacob: that is, A supplanter\f*

And Isaac answered and said unto Esau, Behold, I have made
him thy lord, and all his brethren have I given to him for servants;
and with corn and wine have I sustained him: and what shall I do
now unto thee, my son?\f + \fr 27.37  \ft sustained: or, supported\f*

And Esau said unto his father, Hast thou but one blessing,
my father? bless me, \add even\add* me also, O my father. And Esau
lifted up his voice, and wept.

And Isaac his father answered and said unto him, Behold, thy
dwelling shall be the fatness of the earth, and of the dew of heaven
from above;\f + \fr 27.39  \ft the fatness: or, of the fatness\f*

¶ And Esau hated Jacob because of the blessing wherewith his
father blessed him: and Esau said in his heart, The days of mourning
for my father are at hand; then will I slay my brother Jacob.

And these words of Esau her elder son were told to Rebekah:
and she sent and called Jacob her younger son, and said unto him, Behold, thy
brother Esau, as touching thee, doth comfort himself, \add purposing\add*
to kill thee.

Now therefore, my son, obey my voice; and arise, flee thou to
Laban my brother to Haran;

And tarry with him a few days, until thy brother’s fury turn
away;

Until thy brother’s anger turn away from thee, and he forget
\add that\add* which thou hast done to him: then I will send, and
fetch thee from thence: why should I be deprived also of you both
in one day?

And Rebekah said to Isaac, I am weary of my life because of the
daughters of Heth: if Jacob take a wife of the daughters of Heth, such as these
\add which are\add* of the daughters of the land, what good shall my
life do me?

And Isaac called Jacob, and blessed him, and charged him, and
said unto him, Thou shalt not take a wife of the daughters of Canaan.

Arise, go to Padan-aram, to the house of Bethuel thy mother’s
father; and take thee a wife from thence of the daughters of Laban
thy mother’s brother.

And God Almighty bless thee, and make thee fruitful, and multiply
thee, that thou mayest be a multitude of people;\f + \fr 28.3  \ft a multitude…: Heb. an assembly of
people\f*

And give thee the blessing of Abraham, to thee, and to thy
seed with thee; that thou mayest inherit the land wherein thou art a
stranger, which God gave unto Abraham.\f + \fr 28.4  \ft wherein…: Heb. of thy
sojournings\f*

And Isaac sent away Jacob: and he went to Padan-aram unto Laban,
son of Bethuel the Syrian, the brother of Rebekah, Jacob’s and Esau’s
mother.

¶ When Esau saw that Isaac had blessed Jacob, and sent him away
to Padan-aram, to take him a wife from thence; and that as he blessed
him he gave him a charge, saying, Thou shalt not take a wife of the
daughters of Canaan;

And that Jacob obeyed his father and his mother, and was gone
to Padan-aram;

And Esau seeing that the daughters of Canaan pleased not Isaac
his father;\f + \fr 28.8  \ft pleased…: Heb. were evil in the eyes,
etc\f*

Then went Esau unto Ishmael, and took unto the wives which he had
Mahalath the daughter of Ishmael Abraham’s son, the sister of Nebajoth,
to be his wife.\f + \fr 28.9  \ft Mahalath: or, Bashemath\f*

¶ And Jacob went out from Beer-sheba, and went toward Haran.\f + \fr 28.10 
\ft Haran: Gr. Charran\f*

And he lighted upon a certain place, and tarried there all
night, because the sun was set; and he took of the stones of that
place, and put \add them for\add* his pillows, and lay down in that
place to sleep.

And he dreamed, and behold a ladder set up on the earth, and the top of
it reached to heaven: and behold the angels of God ascending and
descending on it.

And, behold, the \nd LORD\nd* stood above it, and said, I
\add am\add* the \nd LORD\nd* God of Abraham thy father, and the
God of Isaac: the land whereon thou liest, to thee will I give it,
and to thy seed;

And thy seed shall be as the dust of the earth, and thou shalt spread
abroad to the west, and to the east, and to the north, and to the
south: and in thee and in thy seed shall all the families of the
earth be blessed.\f + \fr 28.14  \ft spread…: Heb. break forth\f*

And, behold, I \add am\add* with thee, and will keep thee in all
\add places\add* whither thou goest, and will bring thee again into this
land; for I will not leave thee, until I have done \add that\add*
which I have spoken to thee of.

¶ And Jacob awaked out of his sleep, and he said, Surely the
\nd LORD\nd* is in this place; and I knew \add it\add* not.

And he was afraid, and said, How dreadful \add is\add* this
place! this \add is\add* none other but the house of God, and this
\add is\add* the gate of heaven.

And Jacob rose up early in the morning, and took the stone
that he had put \add for\add* his pillows, and set it up \add for\add*
a pillar, and poured oil upon the top of it.

And he called the name of that place Beth-el: but the name
of that city \add was called\add* Luz at the first.\f + \fr 28.19 
\ft Beth-el: that is, The house of God\f*

And Jacob vowed a vow, saying, If God will be with me, and will keep
me in this way that I go, and will give me bread to eat, and raiment
to put on,

So that I come again to my father’s house in peace; then shall the
\nd LORD\nd* be my God:

And this stone, which I have set \add for\add* a pillar, shall be
God’s house: and of all that thou shalt give me I will surely give the
tenth unto thee.

Then Jacob went on his journey, and came into the land of the
people of the east.\f + \fr 29.1  \ft went…: Heb. lift up his feet\f*\f + \fr 29.1 
\ft people: Heb. children\f*

And he looked, and behold a well in the field, and, lo, there
\add were\add* three flocks of sheep lying by it; for out of that
well they watered the flocks: and a great stone \add was\add* upon the
well’s mouth.

And thither were all the flocks gathered: and they rolled the
stone from the well’s mouth, and watered the sheep, and put the stone
again upon the well’s mouth in his place.

And Jacob said unto them, My brethren, whence \add be\add*
ye? And they said, Of Haran \add are\add* we.

And he said unto them, Know ye Laban the son of Nahor? And they
said, We know \add him\add*.

And he said unto them, \add Is\add* he well? And they said,
\add He is\add* well: and, behold, Rachel his daughter cometh with the
sheep.\f + \fr 29.6  \ft Is he…: Heb. Is there peace to him?\f*

And he said, Lo, \add it is\add* yet high day, neither \add is
it\add* time that the cattle should be gathered together: water ye the
sheep, and go \add and\add* feed \add them\add*.\f + \fr 29.7  \ft it is…: Heb. yet the day is
great\f*

And they said, We cannot, until all the flocks be gathered
together, and \add till\add* they roll the stone from the well’s
mouth; then we water the sheep.

¶ And while he yet spake with them, Rachel came with her father’s
sheep: for she kept them.

And it came to pass, when Jacob saw Rachel the daughter of
Laban his mother’s brother, and the sheep of Laban his mother’s brother,
that Jacob went near, and rolled the stone from the well’s mouth,
and watered the flock of Laban his mother’s brother.
And Jacob kissed Rachel, and lifted up his voice, and wept.

And Jacob told Rachel that he \add was\add* her father’s brother, and that he
\add was\add* Rebekah’s son: and she ran and told her father.

And it came to pass, when Laban heard the tidings of Jacob
his sister’s son, that he ran to meet him, and embraced him, and
kissed him, and brought him to his house. And he told Laban all these
things.\f + \fr 29.13  \ft tidings: Heb. hearing\f*

And Laban said to him, Surely thou \add art\add* my bone and my
flesh. And he abode with him the space of a month.\f + \fr 29.14 
\ft the space…: Heb. a month of days\f*

¶ And Laban said unto Jacob, Because thou \add art\add* my
brother, shouldest thou therefore serve me for nought? tell me, what
\add shall\add* thy wages \add be\add*?

And Laban had two daughters: the name of the elder \add was\add*
Leah, and the name of the younger \add was\add* Rachel.

Leah \add was\add* tender eyed; but Rachel was beautiful and
well favoured.

And Jacob loved Rachel; and said, I will serve thee seven
years for Rachel thy younger daughter.

And Laban said, \add It is\add* better that I give her to thee, than that I should
give her to another man: abide with me.

And Jacob served seven years for Rachel; and they seemed unto him
\add but\add* a few days, for the love he had to her.

¶ And Jacob said unto Laban, Give \add me\add* my wife, for my
days are fulfilled, that I may go in unto her.

And Laban gathered together all the men of the place, and
made a feast.

And it came to pass in the evening, that he took Leah his
daughter, and brought her to him; and he went in unto her.

And Laban gave unto his daughter Leah Zilpah his maid \add for\add*
an handmaid.

And it came to pass, that in the morning, behold, it \add was\add*
Leah: and he said to Laban, What \add is\add* this thou hast done
unto me? did not I serve with thee for Rachel? wherefore then hast thou
beguiled me?

And Laban said, It must not be so done in our country, to
give the younger before the firstborn.\f + \fr 29.26  \ft country: Heb.
place\f*

Fulfil her week, and we will give thee this also for the service
which thou shalt serve with me yet seven other years.

And Jacob did so, and fulfilled her week: and he gave him
Rachel his daughter to wife also.

And Laban gave to Rachel his daughter Bilhah his handmaid
to be her maid.

And he went in also unto Rachel, and he loved also Rachel
more than Leah, and served with him yet seven other years.

¶ And when the \nd LORD\nd* saw that Leah \add was\add* hated,
he opened her womb: but Rachel \add was\add* barren.

And Leah conceived, and bare a son, and she called his name
Reuben: for she said, Surely the \nd LORD\nd* hath looked upon my
affliction; now therefore my husband will love me.\f + \fr 29.32 
\ft Reuben: that is, See a son\f*

And she conceived again, and bare a son; and said, Because the
\nd LORD\nd* hath heard that I \add was\add* hated, he hath therefore
given me this \add son\add* also: and she called his name Simeon.\f + \fr 29.33 
\ft Simeon: that is, Hearing\f*

And she conceived again, and bare a son; and said, Now this
time will my husband be joined unto me, because I have born him three
sons: therefore was his name called Levi.\f + \fr 29.34  \ft Levi: that is,
Joined\f*

And she conceived again, and bare a son: and she said, Now
will I praise the \nd LORD\nd*: therefore she called his name Judah;
and left bearing.\f + \fr 29.35  \ft Judah: that is, Praise\f*\f + \fr 29.35 
\ft left…: Heb. stood from bearing\f*

And when Rachel saw that she bare Jacob no children, Rachel
envied her sister; and said unto Jacob, Give me children, or else
I die.

And Jacob’s anger was kindled against Rachel: and he said,
\add Am\add* I in God’s stead, who hath withheld from thee the fruit
of the womb?

And she said, Behold my maid Bilhah, go in unto her; and she shall
bear upon my knees, that I may also have children by her.\f + \fr 30.3 
\ft have…: Heb. be built by her\f*

And she gave him Bilhah her handmaid to wife: and Jacob went
in unto her.
And Bilhah conceived, and bare Jacob a son.

And Rachel said, God hath judged me, and hath also heard my
voice, and hath given me a son: therefore called she his name Dan.\f + \fr 30.6 
\ft Dan: that is, Judging\f*

And Bilhah Rachel’s maid conceived again, and bare Jacob a
second son.

And Rachel said, With great wrestlings have I wrestled with my
sister, and I have prevailed: and she called his name Naphtali.\f + \fr 30.8 
\ft great…: Heb. wrestlings of God\f*\f + \fr 30.8  \ft Naphtali: that is, My wrestling: Gr.
Nephthalim\f*

When Leah saw that she had left bearing, she took Zilpah her
maid, and gave her Jacob to wife.
And Zilpah Leah’s maid bare Jacob a son.

And Leah said, A troop cometh: and she called his name Gad.\f + \fr 30.11 
\ft Gad: that is, A troop, or, company\f*
And Zilpah Leah’s maid bare Jacob a second son.

And Leah said, Happy am I, for the daughters will call me
blessed: and she called his name Asher.\f + \fr 30.13  \ft Happy…: Heb. In my
happiness\f*\f + \fr 30.13  \ft Asher: that is, Happy\f*

¶ And Reuben went in the days of wheat harvest, and found mandrakes
in the field, and brought them unto his mother Leah. Then Rachel
said to Leah, Give me, I pray thee, of thy son’s mandrakes.

And she said unto her, \add Is it\add* a small matter that thou hast
taken my husband? and wouldest thou take away my son’s mandrakes
also? And Rachel said, Therefore he shall lie with thee to night
for thy son’s mandrakes.

And Jacob came out of the field in the evening, and Leah went
out to meet him, and said, Thou must come in unto me; for surely
I have hired thee with my son’s mandrakes. And he lay with her that
night.

And God hearkened unto Leah, and she conceived, and bare Jacob
the fifth son.

And Leah said, God hath given me my hire, because I have given
my maiden to my husband: and she called his name Issachar.\f + \fr 30.18 
\ft Issachar: that is, An hire\f*
And Leah conceived again, and bare Jacob the sixth son.

And Leah said, God hath endued me \add with\add* a good dowry;
now will my husband dwell with me, because I have born him six sons:
and she called his name Zebulun.\f + \fr 30.20  \ft Zebulun: that is, Dwelling: Gr.
Zabulon\f*

And afterwards she bare a daughter, and called her name Dinah.\f + \fr 30.21 
\ft Dinah: that is Judgment\f*

¶ And God remembered Rachel, and God hearkened to her, and
opened her womb.

And she conceived, and bare a son; and said, God hath taken
away my reproach:

And she called his name Joseph; and said, The \nd LORD\nd*
shall add to me another son.\f + \fr 30.24  \ft Joseph: that is,
Adding\f*

¶ And it came to pass, when Rachel had born Joseph, that Jacob
said unto Laban, Send me away, that I may go unto mine own place,
and to my country.

Give \add me\add* my wives and my children, for whom I have
served thee, and let me go: for thou knowest my service which I have
done thee.

And Laban said unto him, I pray thee, if I have found favour
in thine eyes, \add tarry: for\add* I have learned by experience
that the \nd LORD\nd* hath blessed me for thy sake.
And he said, Appoint me thy wages, and I will give \add it\add*.

And he said unto him, Thou knowest how I have served thee, and
how thy cattle was with me.

For \add it was\add* little which thou hadst before I \add came\add*, and it is
\add now\add* increased unto a multitude; and the \nd LORD\nd* hath
blessed thee since my coming: and now when shall I provide for mine own
house also?\f + \fr 30.30  \ft increased: Heb. broken forth\f*\f + \fr 30.30 
\ft since…: Heb. at my foot\f*

And he said, What shall I give thee? And Jacob said, Thou shalt not
give me any thing: if thou wilt do this thing for me, I will again
feed \add and\add* keep thy flock:

I will pass through all thy flock to day, removing from thence all the
speckled and spotted cattle, and all the brown cattle among the sheep,
and the spotted and speckled among the goats: and \add of such\add*
shall be my hire.

So shall my righteousness answer for me in time to come, when it shall
come for my hire before thy face: every one that \add is\add* not
speckled and spotted among the goats, and brown among the sheep,
that shall be counted stolen with me.\f + \fr 30.33  \ft in time…: Heb. to
morrow\f*

And Laban said, Behold, I would it might be according to thy
word.

And he removed that day the he goats that were ringstraked
and spotted, and all the she goats that were speckled and spotted,
\add and\add* every one that had \add some\add* white in it, and all the
brown among the sheep, and gave \add them\add* into the hand of his
sons.

And he set three days’ journey betwixt himself and Jacob:
and Jacob fed the rest of Laban’s flocks.

¶ And Jacob took him rods of green poplar, and of the hazel
and chesnut tree; and pilled white strakes in them, and made the
white appear which \add was\add* in the rods.

And he set the rods which he had pilled before the flocks
in the gutters in the watering troughs when the flocks came to drink,
that they should conceive when they came to drink.

And the flocks conceived before the rods, and brought forth
cattle ringstraked, speckled, and spotted.

And Jacob did separate the lambs, and set the faces of the
flocks toward the ringstraked, and all the brown in the flock of
Laban; and he put his own flocks by themselves, and put them not unto
Laban’s cattle.

And it came to pass, whensoever the stronger cattle did conceive,
that Jacob laid the rods before the eyes of the cattle in the gutters,
that they might conceive among the rods.

But when the cattle were feeble, he put \add them\add* not
in: so the feebler were Laban’s, and the stronger Jacob’s.

And the man increased exceedingly, and had much cattle, and
maidservants, and menservants, and camels, and asses.

And he heard the words of Laban’s sons, saying, Jacob hath taken
away all that \add was\add* our father’s; and of \add that\add* which
\add was\add* our father’s hath he gotten all this glory.

And Jacob beheld the countenance of Laban, and, behold, it
\add was\add* not toward him as before.\f + \fr 31.2  \ft as before: Heb. as yesterday and the day
before\f*

And the \nd LORD\nd* said unto Jacob, Return unto the land
of thy fathers, and to thy kindred; and I will be with thee.

And Jacob sent and called Rachel and Leah to the field unto his
flock,

And said unto them, I see your father’s countenance, that it
\add is\add* not toward me as before; but the God of my father hath
been with me.
And ye know that with all my power I have served your father.

And your father hath deceived me, and changed my wages ten
times; but God suffered him not to hurt me.

If he said thus, The speckled shall be thy wages; then all the
cattle bare speckled: and if he said thus, The ringstraked shall be thy
hire; then bare all the cattle ringstraked.

Thus God hath taken away the cattle of your father, and given
\add them\add* to me.

And it came to pass at the time that the cattle conceived,
that I lifted up mine eyes, and saw in a dream, and, behold, the
rams which leaped upon the cattle \add were\add* ringstraked, speckled,
and grisled.\f + \fr 31.10  \ft rams: or, he goats\f*

And the angel of God spake unto me in a dream, \add saying\add*,
Jacob: And I said, Here \add am\add* I.

And he said, Lift up now thine eyes, and see, all the rams
which leap upon the cattle \add are\add* ringstraked, speckled, and
grisled: for I have seen all that Laban doeth unto thee.

I \add am\add* the God of Beth-el, where thou anointedst the
pillar, \add and\add* where thou vowedst a vow unto me: now arise,
get thee out from this land, and return unto the land of thy kindred.

And Rachel and Leah answered and said unto him, \add Is there\add*
yet any portion or inheritance for us in our father’s house?

Are we not counted of him strangers? for he hath sold us, and hath
quite devoured also our money.

For all the riches which God hath taken from our father, that
\add is\add* ours, and our children’s: now then, whatsoever God hath
said unto thee, do.
¶ Then Jacob rose up, and set his sons and his wives upon camels;

And he carried away all his cattle, and all his goods which he had
gotten, the cattle of his getting, which he had gotten in Padan-aram,
for to go to Isaac his father in the land of Canaan.

And Laban went to shear his sheep: and Rachel had stolen the
images that \add were\add* her father’s.\f + \fr 31.19  \ft images: Heb.
teraphim\f*

And Jacob stole away unawares to Laban the Syrian, in that
he told him not that he fled.\f + \fr 31.20  \ft unawares…: Heb. the heart of
Laban\f*

So he fled with all that he had; and he rose up, and passed
over the river, and set his face \add toward\add* the mount Gilead.
And it was told Laban on the third day that Jacob was fled.

And he took his brethren with him, and pursued after him seven
days’ journey; and they overtook him in the mount Gilead.

And God came to Laban the Syrian in a dream by night, and
said unto him, Take heed that thou speak not to Jacob either good
or bad.\f + \fr 31.24  \ft either…: Heb. from good to bad\f*

¶ Then Laban overtook Jacob. Now Jacob had pitched his tent
in the mount: and Laban with his brethren pitched in the mount of
Gilead.

And Laban said to Jacob, What hast thou done, that thou hast stolen
away unawares to me, and carried away my daughters, as captives \add taken\add*
with the sword?

Wherefore didst thou flee away secretly, and steal away from me; and didst not
tell me, that I might have sent thee away with mirth, and with songs,
with tabret, and with harp?\f + \fr 31.27  \ft steal…: Heb. hast stolen
me\f*

And hast not suffered me to kiss my sons and my daughters?
thou hast now done foolishly in \add so\add* doing.

It is in the power of my hand to do you hurt: but the God
of your father spake unto me yesternight, saying, Take thou heed
that thou speak not to Jacob either good or bad.

And now, \add though\add* thou wouldest needs be gone, because thou
sore longedst after thy father’s house, \add yet\add* wherefore hast thou
stolen my gods?

And Jacob answered and said to Laban, Because I was afraid:
for I said, Peradventure thou wouldest take by force thy daughters from me.

With whomsoever thou findest thy gods, let him not live: before
our brethren discern thou what \add is\add* thine with me, and take
\add it\add* to thee. For Jacob knew not that Rachel had stolen them.

And Laban went into Jacob’s tent, and into Leah’s tent, and into the
two maidservants’ tents; but he found \add them\add* not. Then went he
out of Leah’s tent, and entered into Rachel’s tent.

Now Rachel had taken the images, and put them in the camel’s
furniture, and sat upon them. And Laban searched all the tent, but
found \add them\add* not.\f + \fr 31.34  \ft searched: Heb. felt\f*

And she said to her father, Let it not displease my lord that I
cannot rise up before thee; for the custom of women \add is\add*
upon me. And he searched, but found not the images.

¶ And Jacob was wroth, and chode with Laban: and Jacob answered
and said to Laban, What \add is\add* my trespass? what \add is\add*
my sin, that thou hast so hotly pursued after me?

Whereas thou hast searched all my stuff, what hast thou found
of all thy household stuff? set \add it\add* here before my brethren
and thy brethren, that they may judge betwixt us both.\f + \fr 31.37 
\ft searched: Heb. felt\f*

This twenty years \add have\add* I \add been\add* with thee; thy
ewes and thy she goats have not cast their young, and the rams of thy
flock have I not eaten.

That which was torn \add of beasts\add* I brought not unto thee; I bare the
loss of it; of my hand didst thou require it, \add whether\add* stolen
by day, or stolen by night.

\add Thus\add* I was; in the day the drought consumed me, and the
frost by night; and my sleep departed  from mine eyes.

Thus have I been twenty years in thy house; I served thee
fourteen years for thy two daughters, and six years for thy cattle:
and thou hast changed my wages ten times.

Except the God of my father, the God of Abraham, and the fear
of Isaac, had been with me, surely thou hadst sent me away now empty.
God hath seen mine affliction and the labour of my hands, and rebuked
\add thee\add* yesternight.

¶ And Laban answered and said unto Jacob, \add These\add* daughters
\add are\add* my daughters, and \add these\add* children \add are\add*
my children, and \add these\add* cattle \add are\add* my cattle,
and all that thou seest \add is\add* mine: and what can I do this
day unto these my daughters, or unto their children which they have
born?

Now therefore come thou, let us make a covenant, I and thou; and let it be for a
witness between me and thee.
And Jacob took a stone, and set it up \add for\add* a pillar.

And Jacob said unto his brethren, Gather stones; and they
took stones, and made an heap: and they did eat there upon the heap.

And Laban called it Jegar-sahadutha: but Jacob called it Galeed.\f + \fr 31.47 
\ft Jegar-sahadutha: that is, The heap of witness, Chaldee\f*\f + \fr 31.47 
\ft Galeed: that is, The heap of witness, Heb.\f*

And Laban said, This heap \add is\add* a witness between me and thee this
day. Therefore was the name of it called Galeed;

And Mizpah; for he said, The \nd LORD\nd* watch between me and thee, when we are
absent one from another.\f + \fr 31.49  \ft Mizpah: that is, A beacon, or,
watchtower\f*

And Laban said to Jacob, Behold this heap, and behold \add this\add*
pillar, which I have cast betwixt me and thee;

This heap \add be\add* witness, and \add this\add* pillar
\add be\add* witness, that I will not pass over this heap to thee, and that thou shalt not pass
over this heap and this pillar unto me, for harm.

The God of Abraham, and the God of Nahor, the God of their
father, judge betwixt us. And Jacob sware by the fear of his father
Isaac.

Then Jacob offered sacrifice upon the mount, and called his
brethren to eat bread: and they did eat bread, and tarried all night
in the mount.\f + \fr 31.54  \ft offered…: or, killed beasts\f*

And early in the morning Laban rose up, and kissed his sons
and his daughters, and blessed them: and Laban departed, and returned
unto his place.
And Jacob went on his way, and the angels of God met him.

And when Jacob saw them, he said, This \add is\add* God’s host:
and he called the name of that place Mahanaim.\f + \fr 32.2  \ft Mahanaim: that is, Two hosts, or,
camps\f*

And Jacob sent messengers before him to Esau his brother unto the
land of Seir, the country of Edom.\f + \fr 32.3  \ft country: Heb.
field\f*

And he commanded them, saying, Thus shall ye speak unto my
lord Esau; Thy servant Jacob saith thus, I have sojourned with Laban,
and stayed there until now:

And I have oxen, and asses, flocks, and menservants, and womenservants:
and I have sent to tell my lord, that I may find grace in thy sight.

¶ And the messengers returned  to Jacob, saying, We came to thy
brother Esau, and also he cometh to meet thee, and four hundred men with him.

And said, If Esau come to the one company, and smite it, then the other
company which is left shall escape.

¶ And Jacob said, O God of my father Abraham, and God of my
father Isaac, the \nd LORD\nd* which saidst unto me, Return unto thy
country, and to thy kindred, and I will deal well with thee:

I am not worthy of the least of all the mercies, and of all the
truth, which thou hast shewed unto thy servant; for with my staff
I passed over this Jordan; and now I am become two bands.\f + \fr 32.10 
\ft I am not…: Heb. I am less than all\f*

Deliver me, I pray thee, from the hand of my brother, from the
hand of Esau: for I fear him, lest he will come and smite me, \add and\add*
the mother with the children.\f + \fr 32.11  \ft with: Heb. upon\f*

And thou saidst, I will surely do thee good, and make thy
seed as the sand of the sea, which cannot be numbered for multitude.

¶ And he lodged there that same night; and took of that which
came to his hand a present for Esau his brother;

Two hundred she goats, and twenty he goats, two hundred ewes,
and twenty rams,

Thirty milch camels with their colts, forty kine, and ten
bulls, twenty she asses, and ten foals.

And he delivered \add them\add* into the hand of his servants,
every drove by themselves; and said unto his servants, Pass over
before me, and put a space betwixt drove and drove.

And he commanded the foremost, saying, When Esau my brother
meeteth thee, and asketh thee, saying, Whose \add art\add* thou? and whither
goest thou? and whose \add are\add* these before thee?

Then thou shalt say, \add They be\add* thy servant Jacob’s; it
\add is\add* a present sent unto my lord Esau: and, behold, also he
\add is\add* behind us.

And so commanded he the second, and the third, and all that
followed the droves, saying, On this manner shall ye speak unto Esau,
when ye find him.

And say ye moreover, Behold, thy servant Jacob \add is\add*
behind us. For he said, I will appease him with the present that
goeth before me, and afterward I will see his face; peradventure he will
accept of me.\f + \fr 32.20  \ft of me: Heb. my face\f*

So went the present over before him: and himself lodged that
night in the company.

And he rose up that night, and took his two wives, and his
two womenservants, and his eleven sons, and passed over the ford
Jabbok.

And he took them, and sent them over the brook, and sent over that he
had.\f + \fr 32.23  \ft sent them: Heb. caused to pass\f*

¶ And Jacob was left alone; and there wrestled a man with him until the
breaking of the day.\f + \fr 32.24  \ft breaking…: Heb. ascending of the
morning\f*

And when he saw that he prevailed not against him, he touched
the hollow of his thigh; and the hollow of Jacob’s thigh was out of
joint, as he wrestled with him.

And he said, Let me go, for the day breaketh. And he said,
I will not let thee go, except thou bless me.

And he said unto him, What \add is\add* thy name? And he said,
Jacob.

And he said, Thy name shall be called no more Jacob, but Israel:
for as a prince hast thou power with God and with men, and hast prevailed.\f + \fr 32.28 
\ft Israel: that is, A prince of God\f*

And Jacob asked \add him\add*, and said, Tell \add me\add*,
I pray thee, thy name. And he said, Wherefore \add is\add* it \add that\add*
thou dost ask after my name? And he blessed him there.

And Jacob called the name of the place Peniel: for I have
seen God face to face, and my life is preserved.\f + \fr 32.30  \ft Peniel: that is, The face of
God\f*

And as he passed over Penuel the sun rose upon him, and he
halted upon his thigh.

Therefore the children of Israel eat not \add of\add* the
sinew which shrank, which \add is\add* upon the hollow of the thigh,
unto this day: because he touched the hollow of Jacob’s thigh in the
sinew that shrank.

And Jacob lifted up his eyes, and looked, and, behold, Esau
came, and with him four hundred men. And he divided the children
unto Leah, and unto Rachel, and unto the two handmaids.

And he put the handmaids and their children foremost, and Leah
and her children after, and Rachel and Joseph hindermost.

And he passed over before them, and bowed himself to the ground
seven times, until he came near to his brother.

And Esau ran to meet him, and embraced him, and fell on his
neck, and kissed him: and they wept.

And he lifted up his eyes, and saw the women and the children;
and said, Who \add are\add* those with thee? And he said, The children
which God hath graciously given thy servant.\f + \fr 33.5  \ft with…: Heb. to
thee\f*

Then the handmaidens came near, they and their children, and they bowed
themselves.

And Leah also with her children came near, and bowed themselves:
and after came Joseph near and Rachel, and they bowed themselves.

And he said, What \add meanest\add* thou by all this drove
which I met? And he said, \add These are\add* to find grace in the
sight of my lord.\f + \fr 33.8  \ft What…: Heb. What is all this band to
thee?\f*

And Esau said, I have enough, my brother; keep that thou hast unto
thyself.\f + \fr 33.9  \ft keep…: Heb. be that to thee that is thine\f*

And Jacob said, Nay, I pray thee, if now I have found grace
in thy sight, then receive my present at my hand: for therefore I have
seen thy face, as though I had seen the face of God, and thou wast pleased with
me.

Take, I pray thee, my blessing that is brought to thee; because
God hath dealt graciously with me, and because I have enough. And he
urged him, and he took \add it\add*.\f + \fr 33.11  \ft enough: Heb. all
things\f*

And he said, Let us take our journey, and let us go, and I will
go before thee.

And he said unto him, My lord knoweth that the children \add are\add*
tender, and the flocks and herds with young \add are\add* with me: and if men should
overdrive them one day, all the flock will die.

Let my lord, I pray thee, pass over before his servant: and I will lead
on softly, according as the cattle that goeth before me and the children
be able to endure, until I come unto my lord unto Seir.\f + \fr 33.14 
\ft according…: Heb. according to the foot of the work, etc., and according to the foot of the
children\f*

And Esau said, Let me now leave with thee \add some\add* of the
folk that \add are\add* with me. And he said, What needeth it? let me
find grace in the sight of my lord.\f + \fr 33.15  \ft leave: Heb. set, or,
place\f*\f + \fr 33.15  \ft What…: Heb. Wherefore is this?\f*
¶ So Esau returned that day on his way unto Seir.

And Jacob journeyed to Succoth, and built him an house, and
made booths for his cattle: therefore the name of the place is called
Succoth.\f + \fr 33.17  \ft Succoth: that is, Booths\f*

¶ And Jacob came to Shalem, a city of Shechem, which \add is\add*
in the land of Canaan, when he came from Padan-aram; and pitched his
tent before the city.\f + \fr 33.18  \ft Shechem: Gr. Sychem\f*

And he bought a parcel of a field, where he had spread his
tent, at the hand of the children of Hamor, Shechem’s father, for an
hundred pieces of money.\f + \fr 33.19  \ft Hamor: Gr. Emmor\f*\f + \fr 33.19 
\ft pieces…: or, lambs\f*

And he erected there an altar, and called it El-elohe-Israel.\f + \fr 33.20 
\ft El-elohe-Israel: that is God the God of Israel\f*

And Dinah the daughter of Leah, which she bare unto Jacob,
went out to see the daughters of the land.

And when Shechem the son of Hamor the Hivite, prince of the
country, saw her, he took her, and lay with her, and defiled her.\f + \fr 34.2 
\ft defiled…: Heb. humbled her\f*

And his soul clave unto Dinah the daughter of Jacob, and he
loved the damsel, and spake kindly unto the damsel.\f + \fr 34.3 
\ft kindly…: Heb. to the heart of the damsel\f*

And Shechem spake unto his father Hamor, saying, Get me this
damsel to wife.

And Jacob heard that he had defiled Dinah his daughter: now his
sons were with his cattle in the field: and Jacob held his peace
until they were come.

¶ And Hamor the father of Shechem went out unto Jacob to commune
with him.

And the sons of Jacob came out of the field when they heard
\add it:\add* and the men were grieved, and they were very wroth,
because he had wrought folly in Israel in lying with Jacob’s daughter;
which thing ought not to be done.

And Hamor communed with them, saying, The soul of my son Shechem
longeth for your daughter: I pray you give her him to wife.

And make ye marriages with us, \add and\add* give your daughters
unto us, and take our daughters unto you.

And ye shall dwell with us: and the land shall be before you;
dwell and trade ye therein, and get you possessions therein.

And Shechem said unto her father and unto her brethren, Let me
find grace in your eyes, and what ye shall say unto me I will give.

Ask me never so much dowry and gift, and I will give according as ye shall
say unto me: but give me the damsel to wife.

And the sons of Jacob answered Shechem and Hamor his father
deceitfully, and said, because he had defiled Dinah their sister:

And they said unto them, We cannot do this thing, to give
our sister to one that is uncircumcised; for that \add were\add*
a reproach unto us:

But in this will we consent unto you: If ye will be as we
\add be\add*, that every male of you be circumcised;

Then will we give our daughters unto you, and we will take
your daughters to us, and we will dwell with you, and we will become
one people.

But if ye will not hearken unto us, to be circumcised; then will we
take our daughter, and we will be gone.
And their words pleased  Hamor, and Shechem Hamor’s son.

And the young man deferred not to do the thing, because he had
delight in Jacob’s daughter: and he \add was\add* more honourable
than all the house of his father.

¶ And Hamor and Shechem his son came unto the gate of their
city, and communed with the men of their city, saying,

These men \add are\add* peaceable with us; therefore let them
dwell in the land, and trade therein; for the land, behold, \add it
is\add* large enough for them; let us take their daughters to us for
wives, and let us give them our daughters.

Only herein will the men consent unto us for to dwell with us, to be
one people, if every male among us be circumcised, as they \add are\add*
circumcised.

\add Shall\add* not their cattle and their substance and every
beast of theirs \add be\add* ours? only let us consent unto them, and they will
dwell with us.

And unto Hamor and unto Shechem his son hearkened all that went
out of the gate of his city; and every male was circumcised, all that went
out of the gate of his city.

¶ And it came to pass on the third day, when they were sore,
that two of the sons of Jacob, Simeon and Levi, Dinah’s brethren,
took each man his sword, and came upon the city boldly, and slew
all the males.

And they slew Hamor and Shechem his son with the edge of the
sword, and took Dinah out of Shechem’s house, and went out.\f + \fr 34.26 
\ft edge: Heb. mouth\f*

The sons of Jacob came upon the slain, and spoiled the city,
because they had defiled their sister.

They took their sheep, and their oxen, and their asses, and that which
\add was\add* in the city, and that which \add was\add* in the field,

And all their wealth, and all their little ones, and their
wives took they captive, and spoiled even all that \add was\add*
in the house.

And Jacob said to Simeon and Levi, Ye have troubled me to make me to
stink among the inhabitants of the land, among the Canaanites and the
Perizzites: and I \add being\add* few in number, they shall gather themselves
together against me, and slay me; and I shall be destroyed, I and my
house.
And they said, Should he deal with our sister as with an harlot?

And God said unto Jacob, Arise, go up to Beth-el, and dwell
there: and make there an altar unto God, that appeared unto thee when thou
fleddest from the face of Esau thy brother.

Then Jacob said unto his household, and to all that \add were\add*
with him, Put away the strange gods that \add are\add* among you,
and be clean, and change your garments:

And let us arise, and go up to Beth-el; and I will make there an
altar unto God, who answered me in the day of my distress, and was with me in the
way which I went.

And they gave unto Jacob all the strange gods which \add were\add*
in their hand, and \add all their\add* earrings which \add were\add*
in their ears; and Jacob hid them under the oak which \add was\add*
by Shechem.

And they journeyed: and the terror of God was upon the cities that
\add were\add* round about them, and they did not pursue after the
sons of Jacob.

¶ So Jacob came to Luz, which \add is\add* in the land of Canaan, that
\add is\add*, Beth-el, he and all the people that \add were\add* with him.

And he built there an altar, and called the place El-beth-el:
because there God appeared unto him, when he fled from the face of his
brother.\f + \fr 35.7  \ft El-beth-el: that is, The God of Beth-el\f*

But Deborah Rebekah’s nurse died, and she was buried beneath
Beth-el under an oak: and the name of it was called Allon-bachuth.\f + \fr 35.8 
\ft Allon-bachuth: that is, The oak of weeping\f*

¶ And God appeared unto Jacob again, when he came out of Padan-aram,
and blessed him.

And God said unto him, Thy name \add is\add* Jacob: thy name
shall not be called any more Jacob, but Israel shall be thy name:
and he called his name Israel.

And the land which I gave Abraham and Isaac, to thee I will give
it, and to thy seed after thee will I give the land.
And God went up from him in the place where he talked with him.

And Jacob set up a pillar in the place where he talked with him,
\add even\add* a pillar of stone: and he poured a drink offering
thereon, and he poured oil thereon.

And Jacob called the name of the place where God spake with him,
Beth-el.

¶ And they journeyed from Beth-el; and there was but a little
way to come to Ephrath: and Rachel travailed, and she had hard labour.\f + \fr 35.16 
\ft a little…: Heb. a little piece of ground\f*

And it came to pass, when she was in hard labour, that the
midwife said unto her, Fear not; thou shalt have this son also.

And it came to pass, as her soul was in departing, (for she
died) that she called his name Ben-oni: but his father called him
Benjamin.\f + \fr 35.18  \ft Ben-oni: that is, The son of my sorrow\f*\f + \fr 35.18 
\ft Benjamin: that is, The son of the right hand\f*

And Rachel died, and was buried in the way to Ephrath, which
\add is\add* Beth-lehem.

And Jacob set a pillar upon her grave: that \add is\add* the
pillar of Rachel’s grave unto this day.

¶ And Israel journeyed, and spread his tent beyond the tower
of Edar.

And it came to pass, when Israel dwelt in that land, that
Reuben went and lay with Bilhah his father’s concubine: and Israel
heard \add it\add*. Now the sons of Jacob were twelve:

The sons of Leah; Reuben, Jacob’s firstborn, and Simeon, and
Levi, and Judah, and Issachar, and Zebulun:
The sons of Rachel; Joseph, and Benjamin:
And the sons of Bilhah, Rachel’s handmaid; Dan, and Naphtali:

And the sons of Zilpah, Leah’s handmaid; Gad, and Asher: these
\add are\add* the sons of Jacob, which were born to him in Padan-aram.

¶ And Jacob came unto Isaac his father unto Mamre, unto the city of
Arbah, which \add is\add* Hebron, where Abraham and Isaac sojourned.
And the days of Isaac were an hundred and fourscore years.

And Isaac gave up the ghost, and died, and was gathered unto his
people, \add being\add* old and full of days: and his sons Esau and
Jacob buried him.

Now these \add are\add* the generations of Esau, who \add is\add*
Edom.

And Bashemath Ishmael’s daughter, sister of Nebajoth.\f + \fr 36.3 
\ft Bashemath: or, Mahalath\f*
And Adah bare to Esau Eliphaz; and Bashemath bare Reuel;

And Aholibamah bare Jeush, and Jaalam, and Korah: these \add are\add*
the sons of Esau, which were born unto him in the land of Canaan.

And Esau took his wives, and his sons, and his daughters, and all the
persons of his house, and his cattle, and all his beasts, and all his
substance, which he had got in the land of Canaan; and went into the
country from the face of his brother Jacob.\f + \fr 36.6  \ft persons: Heb.
souls\f*
Thus dwelt Esau in mount Seir: Esau \add is\add* Edom.

¶ And these \add are\add* the generations of Esau the father
of the Edomites in mount Seir:\f + \fr 36.9  \ft the Edomites: Heb.
Edom\f*

These \add are\add* the names of Esau’s sons; Eliphaz the son
of Adah the wife of Esau, Reuel the son of Bashemath the wife of
Esau.

And the sons of Eliphaz were Teman, Omar, Zepho, and Gatam,
and Kenaz.\f + \fr 36.11  \ft Zepho: or, Zephi\f*

And Timna was concubine to Eliphaz Esau’s son; and she bare
to Eliphaz Amalek: these \add were\add* the sons of Adah Esau’s wife.

And these \add are\add* the sons of Reuel; Nahath, and Zerah,
Shammah, and Mizzah: these were the sons of Bashemath Esau’s wife.

¶ And these were the sons of Aholibamah, the daughter of Anah
the daughter of Zibeon, Esau’s wife: and she bare to Esau Jeush,
and Jaalam, and Korah.

¶ These \add were\add* dukes of the sons of Esau: the sons
of Eliphaz the firstborn \add son\add* of Esau; duke Teman, duke
Omar, duke Zepho, duke Kenaz,

Duke Korah, duke Gatam, \add and\add* duke Amalek: these \add are\add*
the dukes \add that came\add* of Eliphaz in the land of Edom; these
\add were\add* the sons of Adah.

¶ And these \add are\add* the sons of Reuel Esau’s son; duke
Nahath, duke Zerah, duke Shammah, duke Mizzah: these \add are\add*
the dukes \add that came\add* of Reuel in the land of Edom; these
\add are\add* the sons of Bashemath Esau’s wife.

These \add are\add* the sons of Esau, who \add is\add* Edom, and these
\add are\add* their dukes.

¶ These \add are\add* the sons of Seir the Horite, who inhabited
the land; Lotan, and Shobal, and Zibeon, and Anah,

And Dishon, and Ezer, and Dishan: these \add are\add* the
dukes of the Horites, the children of Seir in the land of Edom.

And the children of Lotan were Hori and Hemam; and Lotan’s
sister \add was\add* Timna.\f + \fr 36.22  \ft Hemam: or, Homam\f*

And the children of Shobal \add were\add* these; Alvan, and
Manahath, and Ebal, Shepho, and Onam.\f + \fr 36.23  \ft Alvan: or,
Alian\f*\f + \fr 36.23  \ft Shepho: or, Shephi\f*

And these \add are\add* the children of Zibeon; both Ajah,
and Anah: this \add was that\add* Anah that found the mules in the
wilderness, as he fed the asses of Zibeon his father.

And the children of Anah \add were\add* these; Dishon, and
Aholibamah the daughter of Anah.

And these \add are\add* the children of Dishon; Hemdan, and
Eshban, and Ithran, and Cheran.\f + \fr 36.26  \ft Hemdan: or, Amram\f*

The children of Ezer \add are\add* these; Bilhan, and Zaavan,
and Akan.\f + \fr 36.27  \ft Akan: or, Jakan\f*
The children of Dishan \add are\add* these; Uz, and Aran.

These \add are\add* the dukes \add that came\add* of the Horites;
duke Lotan, duke Shobal, duke Zibeon, duke Anah,

Duke Dishon, duke Ezer, duke Dishan: these \add are\add* the
dukes \add that came\add* of Hori, among their dukes in the land
of Seir.

¶ And these \add are\add* the kings that reigned in the land
of Edom, before there reigned any king over the children of Israel.

And Bela the son of Beor reigned in Edom: and the name of his
